Key to the genera of Pittosporaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.; Albrecht, D.E.
source.title: Pittosporaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G.; Albrecht, D.E. (1996). Pittosporaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flowers with petals semi-spreading from base, bright blue (rarely white); anthers longer than filaments, coherent at apex (at least when young)
Flowers more or less tubular, yellow, green, orange or pale bluish; anthers shorter than filaments, free
Flowers 3–12 together, in terminal cymes; corolla white or purplish
Flowers solitary or paired (rarely in 3s), corolla green, yellowish or orange
Inflorescence  ± sessile in leaf axil; petals white with a red marking in throat, petals often becoming darker in colour with age
Inflorescence a lax cyme, shortly pedunculate, peduncle > 5 mm long; flowers reddish or blue, rarely white
Corolla 25 mm long or more; style about as long as corolla; petals shortly spreading near the tips; leaves and stems shining and glabrous; berry purplish, shining, 2-locular

Corolla 12–25 mm long; style up to c. half length of corolla; petals spreading from about the middle; at least the younger leaves and stems hairy, older leaves remaining dull; berry dull, greenish, unilocular

Twining shrubs; leaves mostly narrowly elliptic or ovate with flat or undulate margins; pedicels slender, pendulous or curving, 12–45 mm long in flower, often extending in fruit; ovary and fruit glabrous or rarely pubescent
Ascending shrubs; leaves c. oblong, usually with distinctly recurved margins; pedicels stout, erect or sometimes pendulous, up to 12 mm long in fruit; ovary and fruit densely villous
